posts.name:
Heather Wilson, CMP, CITI
Heather Wilson, CMP, CITI
posts.content:
How did I earn shares in a FinTech startup, build two functions from the ground up, and then launch my consultancy‚Äîachieving six-figure profit in under six months, continuing to grow year over year?

Years of learning, life-lessons and choosing a company with visionary leadership.

The kind of leadership that turns uncertainty and risk into opportunity. That keeps teams motivated when the stakes are high. That transforms employees into true stakeholders, fostering a shared sense of ownership and purpose. If employees have a stake in the company, they need leaders who are self-aware enough to understand that those employees should hold them accountable for their decisions.

In my case, this approach wasn‚Äôt just theoretical‚Äîit paid off in a very real way. I didn‚Äôt just earn shares; I realized them. Those shares became a tangible reward for the work I put into driving growth, navigating challenges and delivering results in a high-stakes startup environment.

That payout was more than a financial milestone‚Äîit was proof that everyone wins when leaders inspire collective accountability and empower their teams to invest in a shared vision. It was also a lesson that I could build for myself *and* others at the same time.

I learned from the best (and the worst, but that's a story for another day). This mindset has fueled my career and shaped my journey.

So, here‚Äôs my challenge to you: If you're at a startup and/or you have shares in your company, don‚Äôt just hold them‚Äîown them. Ask questions. Expect answers. Advocate for yourself. Flourish in the shared success that true accountability can bring.

comments.commentText: Your approach to owning your role and shares in the company is empowering The emphasis you've shown on accountability and active participation is truly motivating Heather Wilson, CMP, CITI Ô∏è

posts.name:
Alex Turnbull
Alex Turnbull
posts.content:
"AI isn't just replacing us‚Äìit's watching us first.‚Äù

Last week I was in a side room at a tech meet up with the VP of Engineering of a $200M ARR SaaS platform. They were showing me something on their laptop. Here's what they shared:

"AI isn't just replacing us‚Äìit's watching us first. 30% productivity gains at Salesforce?

That's from AI studying every workflow, every pattern, and every process.

Benioff just announced: zero engineering hires in 2025, but 2,000 new salespeople instead?

January layoffs aren't random; they're evolutionary.

They need humans to sell what AI helps build.

Everything feels like we're at an inflection point. Nothing about this feels optional. Nothing about this path seems reversible."

We're in the most transformative tech shift that any of us have experienced.

You weren't a genius when AI was just hype.

You weren't ready when AI was just watching.

And you're not obsolete now that it's learning.

We're all part of this transition. Part of this evolution.

Yes, there are things we can do to adapt and thrive.

But also, remember to understand what's really happening:

When AI can handle 80% of routine work by learning from our patterns, when Salesforce completely freezes engineering hiring but adds 2,000 salespeople, we're not just entering a new era.

We're entering the next phase of human-AI collaboration.

The question isn't if AI will change engineering.

It's how we'll evolve with it.

Like every technological revolution, those who adapt first will shape what comes next.

comments.commentText: Things will move very quickly once someone creates an AI that can actually think for itself and grow beyond a language or generative model (and one that isn't prohibitively expensive)
Chris Chambers All of which seems very close at hand.
This revolution is the tech version of advancing from steam power to gas to electric... all in less than a decade. Wild (exciting) times

posts.name:
Josh Matthews
Josh Matthews
posts.content:
2025 Salesforce Predictions: Are You Ready?

2024 was a transformative year for the Salesforce ecosystem, with AI taking center stage. Tools like AgentForce and Data Cloud revolutionized how businesses operate, automating repetitive tasks and streamlining operations. But with this innovation came challenges, from navigating AI implementation to the ripple effects on job dynamics.

Looking ahead, 2025 is set to bring more opportunities for professionals who adapt. Multi-cloud expertise will become essential as businesses integrate tools like Revenue Cloud, Marketing Cloud, and Service Cloud to drive results. Business analysts will be in high demand to ensure smooth processes and strategic alignment, while hiring managers will focus on candidates with a mix of technical skills and interpersonal abilities.

The human element will remain irreplaceable. Communication, empathy, and problem-solving will define top performers in an AI-enhanced world. To thrive, professionals must not only stay current with certifications but also build strong networks and document their achievements.

Dive into the full article below to explore the key trends from 2024 and actionable insights to succeed in 2025.

posts.name:
Jason Bay
Jason Bay
posts.content:
7 hard truths about outbound in 2025:

Ô∏è 1) Mass blast is destroying your TAM

You can never email a prospect who unsubscribes. You can never call a prospect on your do not call list. And you can never email ANYONE in a target account that blocks your company's entire domain.

Stop doing this to your buyers.


Ô∏è 2) Buyers want way more from you before committing to a meeting

We've squeezed all of the juice out of: "All we need is 15 min..." Then it was 10 min. Then 5 min.

The ask for time can't get any shorter.

The value in return for time has to increase:

- Site audits
- Experiencing the brand
- Sharing insights
- Mystery shopping the brand
- Surfacing insights from ICs/managers on their team
etc.


Ô∏è 3) Well-written, customized, relevant, etc. cold emails aren't enough anymore

They just aren't. You could get 15-20%+ reply rates from okay cold emails that were personalized.

Inboxes are too cluttered. World-class cold emails aren't making it through as much anymore.

You have to be multi-channel: email, phone, social, physical mail, dropping by in-person, etc.


Ô∏è 4) Your reps don't outbound because your front-line leaders don't know how

Many front-line leaders crushed it from ~2010-2020. The economy was at an all-time HIGH. Everything was great.

They didn't have to outbound as much. They worked on teams that were over-hired with SDRs. And inbound was poppin'.

They never learned how to do outbound. And THAT is why your reps don't outbound.


Ô∏è 5) Many reps are afraid to call cell phones

I see this every week in training calls with large sales orgs.

Reps are asking: "But isn't it weird to call someone's cell phone? Feels like I'm violating their privacy."

So what do they end up doing? Call general office lines. Talking all day to gatekeepers.

Or worse, ditching the phone altogether.


Ô∏è 6) It's hard to make cold calling work without a dialer

Pick-up rates are <5-6% for most sales teams right now.

That math just ain't mathin' for Account Executives.

- 25 calls per day (takes about an hour) x 5 days per week = 125 calls
- 125 calls x 5% pick-up rate = ~6 conversations
- ~6 converations x 10-15% avg. conversion rate = 1 meeting

You'll get 3-5x+ that with a dialer.


Ô∏è 7) The ceiling of outbound success is your marketing engine

Marketing can't take credit for a sales-sourced meeting. It's too hard to track.

But I've never seen a great outbound org that didn't have world-class marketing.

Cold calling for a well-known brand like Shopify hits different than a startup no one's heard about before.


~~~


What would you add to the list?

comments.commentText:
I see no lies, especially 5 & 6. 
I‚Äôd add - you need to max how you use each channel. 

EG. Don‚Äôt just make cold calls, explore how you can use text and voice notes and ABSOLUTELY make sure you are scripting your voicemails so can they can be easily listened to or read and use those VMs to point to other touches on different channels!

posts.name:
Ranveer Allahbadia
Ranveer Allahbadia
posts.content:
Hindu - A word used by ancient people of the Gulf and Central Asia. A word that represented the entire collection of people on the OTHER side of the Indu (Indus) River. ‚ÄúThose people are the Hindus‚Äù

Hinduism is a collection of philosophies, teachings and thought processes from the countless texts that were written in the Indian subcontinent (Gita, Vedas, Upanishads, Puranas)

A very interesting aspect of Indian philosophy is the ‚ÄúLeft Hand Of God‚Äù - The alternate, faster, but more dangerous path.

comments.commentText: It‚Äôs always enlightening to dive deeper into Hinduism's rich philosophies and teachings.

Gosh, what a fascinating perspective on the term "Hindu"! It‚Äôs amazing how language shapes our understanding of culture. 

The depth of Indian philosophy is truly a treasure trove. Would love to hear more!

posts.name:
Business Development - The Missing Link Between Marketing & Sales - 540,000 Members Strong
Business Development - The Missing Link Between Marketing & Sales - 540,000 Members Strong

Remington Rawlings
Remington Rawlings
posts.content:
Meet the team.

Extraordinary people solving extraordinary problems means doing extraordinary things.

We are built to last because ofas CTO andas Founding Engineer, together leading our engineering efforts.

We are positioned for a uniquely special product market fit withand her team as she leads product.

Behind the scenes working closely with me is, my Chief of Staff and administrative wizard.

And just this week after advising us the last year,has officially hiredas Head of Sales full-time, helping us grow.

Together as a team, we have some big announcements you'll start to see over the next few weeks as we execute on our rollout plans.

But I want to say 2 things before this snowball of progress truly takes off.

1. You won't regret living your values

We won't win because we are the smartest or the most advanced, or the most well funded, or the most connected.

We are going to impact things because we have cared about actually solving a real problem since Day 1.

Last year after Unleash, we had over $1.5 million in sales pipeline, much of it progressing to close quickly. And as I was about to close deals, I found egregious errors that led me to realize, "We gotta pull the plug."

We didn't sell software, on purpose.

This last year was a year of rebuilding following that. We made personnel changes. We redid the entire code base from end to end. We revamped our calculations.

And now, we are bulletproof.

That delay brought stress.

We still sold services.

But we demonstrated we don't trade integrity for anything at OneView.

We make impact through data-driven analysis.

That starts with our willingness to be patient and make sound decisions, or else how can we help our customers do that?

2nd point: You won't regret deeply creative thinking

As a consultancy turned productized bootstrapped startup, we have gotten "around" many norms and stipulations startups face.

We avoided big funding rounds, inflated valuations, unneeded dilution, and constant scrutiny of the plans we have been making before we "knew it cold."

Now we do, and the path has never been clearer.

We must always demand of ourselves the type of innovation we never thought was possible.

We have used every flavor of AI and technology imaginable, without yet needing certain full-time hires for unneeded things.

And already we have analysis capabilities that quite literally don't exist anywhere else in the entire market (prove me wrong, I'll show you).

What we sell next will change markets.

But the quality in that process is not just the outcome, it's the process itself.

People say the destination is the journey, which can sound like excusing failure.

For my part, I believe living our values and thinking creatively are a journey that must be taken if the ultimate destination is to be achieved.

Who is ready to come and see what we have been cooking up?

comments.commentText: I‚Äôve done a lot of things in my career that I‚Äôm proud of, and I‚Äôve worked with some amazing teams. Don‚Äôt think I‚Äôve ever been more excited, or more confident about the impact we can make. Looking forward to introducing the world the!
